content.description: Zero to Sixty-Nine is a fun, but short, route that begins with some 5.11 moves before blasting your way past the final bolt to the top. The final few moves are challenging and worthwhile.
content.location:
This climbs the slightly overhanging face to the left of

Slapaho

.

content.description:
Get the first clip before starting. It is useful to drop back to the ground and use a slight variation for the actual climbing.  A tricky move off the deck leads to the crux at the second bolt.  Another clip and the anchors is the whole story.

Very pumpy for such a short route. Your Brain on Rain shares an anchor with

Swinging in the Rain

, and this provides a convenient top rope, if you are not  up to leading the mantle move on

Swinging

. Or, set it up vice-versa.

N.B.: Your Brain leans a lot to the left and this makes for some TR problems, if that is what you plan on doing. Good place in the rain, but don't expect much sun.
content.protection: QDs only. This 35 foot route needs three to four draws and something for the double bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: Your Brain is the furthest route on the right side of the crag, just past some blocks.

content.description: This is the leftmost bolted line on the crag.  Like everything else on Rainy Day Rock, it is short, but it packs a wallop.  When I first did it, it seemed straightforward.  When I came back on another occasion, it was a real bear and I couldn't figure out what I did before.  In the process of working it out again I slipped off a smear and got a nasty, bloody shin-banger on the lip of an overlap.  I eventually succeeded, but only at a cost.  It may be more difficult than .11b.  I don't think it is much easier.
content.protection: Three bolts [now removed?] to a two bolt anchor.

content.description: This route starts with a crux mantle past the first bolt onto a large sloping ledge.  Anyway you try it, it is a solid 5.11 move that has befuddled many a 5.12 leader.  The real trick is avoiding the "Beached Whale Syndrome", flopping around until you slide off backwards.  From the ledge, nice overhanging reaches between 5.10 jugs take you to the anchors.
content.protection: Three bolts to a two bolt anchor.

content.description:
Just left of

Rainy Day 12a

, is a super steep corner. It has hard bouldering to get into it and a few thin moves to get the top jug. This is a good tick for boulderers who want to put on a rope.

Who would imagine that the authors of the Clear Creek Classic, Sonic Youth, would stuff a tiny little line in here? Why not? Even The General needs to climb in the rain.

A crimpy start and a clip from the ground will get you into the dihedral and polish the crux. Chase the corner for a few more clips; pop up over  the block above the dihedral to clip the anchors. Pretty cool over all, and a lot of pump delivered in 35 feet. Good edge training for the fingers. The Rainy Day anchor will allow you to top rope the 5.13 which is a lot trickier than it looks as well.
content.protection: QDs only. This 35 foot route needs 4-5 draws and something for the double bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: Rainy Day 12A starts in the middle of the overhang, third route from the right and adjacent to an amazingly powerful 5.13 on its left.

content.description: This route tackles the bad-sized crack on the prominent overhanging prow in the middle of the crag.  A combination to jamming and liebacking runs to the top of the crack.  A big reach to a match on the sloping lip allows you to clip the anchors.  Half the fun is hanging on the lip to make the clip.  Mantling the sloping shelf past the anchor and standing up into the choss above would add significantly to the difficulty, and is left as an exercise for the next generation.
content.protection: Three bolts to a pair of anchor bolts with goldshuts.

content.description:
Climb the left-leaning crack/corner to a shared anchor with "

Thunder Road

".
content.protection: Small wires to 1.5" cam, two [one?] anchor bolts.
